awd_titl_txt: Study of Wavelength Dependence of Plasma Collision Dynamics and Ionization Mechanism in Laser Solid Matter Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will improve the understanding of plasma collision dynamics when high power lasers interact with solid materials. With more than 99.9% of visible matter in the universe known to be in a plasma state, it is important to understand the physics of particle ionization, charge collision, and light propagation and absorption in a plasma. One method for producing and studying plasma in laboratories is using high power lasers.  When materials are irradiated by high power lasers, bound electrons in atoms and molecules can be freed (i.e., ionized) and thus plasma is created. Laser-plasma interactions during and after material ionization exhibit a lot of interesting phenomena. For example, free electron acceleration by lasers can produce high-energy radiation such as ultraviolet and x-ray light when the accelerated electrons collide with ions. In this project, the laser wavelength dependence of the plasma collision dynamics in solids will be experimentally and theoretically investigated. This project will also promote basic science education to groups who have been traditionally underrepresented in science by hosting science camps for grandparent-headed families and for middle school students of rural families.

Since electron collision plays an important role in plasmas, systematic studies on the electron collision frequency are critical for understanding the laser plasma interaction correctly. In this project, the plasma dynamics in solids under laser irradiation will be experimentally studied by measuring both electron collision times and plasma densities using femtosecond-time-resolved interferometry. In particular, the effect of the driver wavelength on plasma dynamics will be investigated. The experiments will also be benchmarked against computer simulations of laser matter interactions. This research will significantly contribute to furthering understanding of wavelength scaling of the laser matter interaction in solids. Furthermore, this study will impact laser-plasma-based technology such as laser-plasma accelerators and provide guidance for high energy density physics using terawatt and petawatt peak power lasers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bonggu Shim, PI, Binghamton University, NSF 2010365 “Study of Wavelength Dependence of Plasma Collision Dynamics and Ionization Mechanism in Laser Solid Matter Interactions”

Electron collision time (or frequency) is an important parameter in various subjects of plasma physics such as energy transport, wave damping, material damage, and light absorption and propagation. However, there is little literature on measuring the electron collision time during laser matter interactions despite its importance. In this project, we have experimentally measured electron collision times and plasma densities in solids with various wavelengths by employing state-of-the-art time-resolved visualization methods. Furthermore, to be benchmarked against the experiments, we have carried out high-profile numerical simulations for laser plasma interactions and nonlinear propagation.  In detail,

1)  We have investigated wavelength scaling of plasma dynamics by measuring the electron collision time in plasma for ultrashort laser filamentation in solids. Laser filamentation is self-guidance of a high-power laser pulse due to the dynamic balance among various nonlinear effects such as self-focusing and plasma-induced defocusing. According to our experiment using transverse time-resolved interferometry and wavelengths spanning near-infrared and mid-infrared, the electron collision time decreases with increasing wavelength in laser filamentation in solids. The observed wavelength scaling of the electron collision time is mainly due to hotter electron generation at longer wavelengths via laser ponderomotive heating. Our study shows that electron collision times should be systematically measured to correctly understand the dynamics of high-intensity laser plasma interactions. 

2) However, the time-resolved interferometric measurement was applied only to weakly-ionized (less than  0.1 % ionization) plasma because laser intensities in filaments are clamped due to the balance between plasma-induced defocusing and self-focusing. Thus, to extend the research to a larger scope of laser-plasma interactions such as highly-ionized plasma, we conduct laser-matter interaction experiments in thin (100 µm) glass samples to avoid laser filamentation and resulting weak ionization. In particular, we employ state-of-the-art single-shot frequency-domain holography (FDH) to measure plasma densities and electron collision times for strong field laser-plasma interactions. Furthermore, we have successfully implemented variable-color FDH using a tunable-wavelength optical parametric amplifier light source to study the wavelength-dependent laser plasma interaction in a single shot. We also studied the dynamics of ionization and rotational Raman effects of gas molecules such as CO2  under a strong laser field using the single-shot FDH technique.  

3) We carry out high-profile numerical simulations using laser matter/plasma interaction codes such as nonlinear envelope equations and unidirectional pulse propagation equations. Using the codes, we have successfully guided and explained our experiments as well as collaborators’ experiments. In addition, we successfully made robust simulation codes for high-order harmonic generation (HHG), which is a source of tabletop ultrashort ultraviolet/soft x-ray light and theoretically studied efficient soft x-ray generation via HHG when a driving laser pulse undergoes nonlinear propagation in a long gas cell.

We have been promoting basic science education including plasma, lasers, and optics to groups who have been traditionally underrepresented in science in Broome County of New York by hosting science camps for grandparent-headed families and for middle school students of rural families since January 2014. Due to COVID-19, we hosted online science camps in September 2020. In the online camps, children and students assembled science kits including solar-powered cars under the online supervision of the PI's group. We have hosted in-person summer science camps again since summer, 2021.

In this project,  4 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students have been supported and trained. G. Nagar successfully defended and received her doctoral degree in December 2021 and also received a Graduate Student Award for Excellence in Research from Binghamton University. J. Agnes won an award in the student poster competition of the 34th annual Electronics Packaging Symposium in 2023.
